bibl.title: Letter from Fred L. Soper to J.F. Siler, February 23, 1950

div1.p: Soper suggests wording for the proposed Reed plaque.

div1.head: Letter from Fred L. Soper to J.F. Siler, February 23, 1950
div1.opener:
COPY
PAN AMERICAN SANITARY BUREAU
Regional Office of the
WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION
2001 Connecticut Ave., N.W.
Washington, 8, D.C.
February 23, 1950.
Colonel J. F. Siler, Secretary
Walter Reed Memorial Association
2220- 20th Street, N.W.
Washington, 9, D.C.
Dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
In accordance with our telephone conversation this morning, I
wish to register my agreement with the suggestion that the Walter Reed
plaque should carry some wording identifying him with yellow fever.

I cannot go along with the proposed wording “Conqueror of
Yellow Fever,” since a full quarter of a century after Walter Reed's
death a number of deaths of laboratory investigators of yellow fever
did occur thus dramatically calling attention to the incompleteness of
our victory over yellow fever at that time. Even today, yellow fever
is a serious threat to exposed populations in many parts of South America
and Africa.

I would suggest two alternatives depending upon how large a
plaque is to be made and the space available for wording:

WALTER REED
who demonstrated the mosquito
transmission of yellow fever
died in a hospital
on this site
Nov. 23- 1902

WALTER REED
of yellow fever fame
died in a hospital
on this site
Nov. 23- 1902
With kindest personal regards, I remain
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, signed: Fred L. Soper
Director.
